 MADAGASCAR PUBLIC MANAGEMENT CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT Technical Annex SECTION A: DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION 1. The following section provides background and technical information on the proposed project and consists of four chapters: Chapter I presents the country background, Chapter 11 describes public sector issues, Chapter III presents the project rationale and a detailed description of the development assistance objectives it will serve, and Chapter IV describes project benefits and risks. I. Country and Operation Background 2. At US$430 in the early 1960s, Madagascar's per capita income was in line with that of Indonesia (US$480), and was close to that of Thailand (US$620). Thirty years later, at US$230, Madagascar's per capita income has declined to about half its level at the time of independence, is less than one-third Indonesia's (US$740), and is about one-tenth Thailand's (US$2,100). Indonesia and Thailand are just two among many other developing countries that have been able to grow at much faster rates than Madagascar which, in essence, has lost three decades of economic development. It is thus not surprising that Madagascar's economy has provided its population (now 13 million people, of which 80 percent live and work in rural areas) few opportunities to improve their living standards. Whereas the incidence of poverty has significantly declined in Indonesia, Thailand and other developing countries, it has increased in Madagascar. The proportion of the population living in poverty (that is, consuming less than what is necessary to meet basic nutritional requirements) has increased from 43 percent in the 1960s to close to 75 percent in the early 1990s. The evolution described by these statistics is matched by the population's palpable sense that its standards of living have declined over time. The population's sense of impoverishment is accentuated by a decline in its health and educational standards and, perhaps more importantly, by little evidence that the country's current development policies will significantly improve its economic prospects. 3. Two factors have contributed to this situation: ill-advised economic policies pursued in the last 25 years and population growth of almost 3 percent per year. For 10 years following its independence in 1960, Madagascar enjoyed modest average growth of about 3 percent per year. However, even that faltered in the mid-1970s, as the country underwent a socialist revolution that brought authoritarian rule and interventionist economic policies. Widespread nationalization and extensive controls led to a long period of economic decline, and large public investments in the late 1970s created "white elephants", severe macro-economic imbalances, and a heavy debt burden. In the mid-1980s, the government initiated reforms, supported by Bank- financed sectoral adjustment operations; although growth resumed, the decline in living standards was not reversed. 4. In mid-1991, demonstrations and strikes in support of political liberalization swept the country and signaled the start of a lengthy transition to pluralistic democracy. The adoption of a new constitution in August 1992 led to the election of President Albert Zafy and a new national assembly, as well as the accession of a new govemment under Prime Minister Francisque
 2 Ravony in 1993. All these changes occurred peacefully after free and fair elections. During the transition period, however, the reforms and adjustment program derailed. 5. In 1994, the economic situation continued to deteriorate and the GDP stagnated. After floating the exchange rate in May and designing the complete policy agenda for a Policy Framework Paper (PFP), the government allowed inflation to mount through lax monetary management and an ill-conceived, large-scale program of petroleum and commodity subsidies that increased the budget deficit. In January 1995, the government replaced the management of the Central Bank, declared its intention to implement adjustment policies and agreed with the IMF on a stabilization plan to bring down the inflation rate. Tensions between the President and the Prime Minister (PM) led to a national referendum in September 1995, which shifted authority to choose the PM from the National Assembly to the President. As a result, the former PM stepped down and was replaced by Emmanuel Rakotovahiny, who formed a new government in November 1995. Economic performance in 1995 was still mediocre, with a further decrease in real per capita GDP. Political infighting continued in late 1995/early 1996, with increased debate centered on the issue of economic reform. In May 1996, the PM received a "no confidence" vote from the National Assembly, and the President appointed Norbert Ratsirahonana, previously head of the High Constitutional Court, as PM. The new PM has indicated that he wants to move quickly on an IMF/Bank-supported adjustment program, as well as on capacity building initiatives. 6. Economic measures implemented thus far include floating of the exchange rate, sharp price increases for energy and the elimination of commodity subsidies. Recently, the government began action to divest the state from the banking sector, prepare a full scale divestiture of public enterprises, strengthen the incentives for private sector development, and create a safety net to combat poverty. Public expenditures have remained relatively low at about 20 percent of GDP while the composition of the public investment program has improved (see below). These moves, if sustained, will help restore the government's credibility, while preparing the ground for further assistance by the Bank and IMF and possible debt relief from the Paris Club. 7. In the absence of a structural adjustment program, the policy dialogue with the new government has remained intense and fruitful. In spite of policy lapses, key decisions, such as the reform of the exchange rate system and the liberalization of the petroleum sector, have been achieved. These significant measures are still not enough to fully qualify for adjustment lending and for the confidence of the investor community. Key areas in which a consensus for reform is growing but are still the subject of a dialogue with the donor community include government disengagement from the banking system, privatization, and private sector development. The proposed project is a necessary underpinning of the efforts to help the Government get over that threshold by helping implement improvements in areas in which there is already strong government commitment and supporting consensus building in the remaining areas. 8. To take further reforms that are envisaged, there is a need for economic intelligence work. There is also a need to strengthen overall the public administration, which is unable to perform adequately basic public services. These needs were identified through the implementation of the Economic Management and Social Action Project (EMSAP), dialogue with the IMF and other donors, OED reports, and the Private Sector Assessment (PSA). The proposed project aims at enabling Malagasy institutions to implement needed reforms and improved management.
 3 II. The Project Project Rationale 9. Since the political transition to democratic rule started in 1991, the political leaders have had difficulties in formulating a clear vision of an economic strategy for growth which would allow the population to emerge from its present situation of extreme poverty. Political infighting, lack of leadership and conflicting short-term goals have been the reason for this immobilism. After four years, the government seems to have reached an agreement on a reform program and is pursuing discussions with the Bretton Woods Institutions on a structural adjustment program. As a recent OED audit (February 1995) of structural adjustment programs in Madagascar points out, these programs can only be successful if they take into account capacity constraints in delivering technically complex reforms as well as the need for consensus building. This issue was also stressed in a 1995 Borrower Feedback Survey. This creates a need for well-targeted technical operations to prepare the ground for a wide-ranging economic reform program. 10. IDA's comparative advantage. The project focuses on capacity building in areas where IDA support has already been successfully provided under the EMSAP, which need to be consolidated to ensure long term sustainability of ongoing reforms. New areas of intervention are proposed in response to Madagascar's urgent need to improve governance. IDA is well positioned to provide this support due to extensive lessons that have been drawn from past experience with technical assistance operations and recent innovative initiatives, for example on a participatory approach to civil service reform. Close cooperation with donors that have significant experience in handling specific project components (such as EUROSTAT in strengthening of INSTAT, USAID in legal and judiciary reform and the communication strategy, and the French cooperation in strengthening the Ministries of Finance, Budget and Planning, and support to decentralization and legal and judiciary reform) has helped to improve project design. Project Description 11. Project purpose. The proposed project would provide assistance to the government to build capacity to implement economic reforms and improve public administration. * Economic management. By reinforcing the agencies responsible for macroeconomic management, the project would improve the government's capacity to design and implement an economic reform program and contribute to a sharper focus on poverty alleviation in allocating public resources. As insufficient information on adjustment and economic reform has been highlighted as an important reason for a lack of public support for adjustment, the project would help prepare a public information campaign. * Public administration. The project would facilitate a fiscally responsible implementation of the decentralization process, thus avoiding the waste of public resources; it would foster participation in local planning and management of the development process while also encouraging accountability; it would catalyze
 4 consensus building on civil service reform within the administration, leading to greater commitment to reform. Finally, the project aims at making effective the "rule of law" and improving security of business transactions through the independence and increased effectiveness of the judiciary. Overall, the project would help the administration, civil service, and judicial system embrace a new vision of the role of government -- another critical precondition for a successful transition to a private sector driven economy. This is by essence a long-term endeavor. The project's goal is to start the process by focusing on a few achievable, but significant, areas where feasibility is demonstrated. A detailed description of the project components and sub-components is provided below. A. Strengthening Economic Management 1. Monitoring and Implementing Economic Reforms 12. In March 1995, the government, with an eye toward preparing a new structural adjustmnent program, decided to reinforce its capacity to design and analyze economic policy. A technical support unit, the Technical Secretariat for Adjustment (STA), was created. Initial STA activities have been supported with technical assistance under the ongoing EMSAP. The STA consists of three members: a Secretary General and two technical experts, one in charge of macro-economic policies and the other of sectoral policies. The STA has direct access to the Prime Minister and plays a crucial role in informing and advising on the timely implementation of reform measures and assures a steady flow of information between financial and technical ministries, the private sector, and donor agencies. Several technicai committees facilitate its work. The first, Comite des Reformes Macro-Economiques et Financieres (COREMEF), establishes the macro-economic framework, while the second, Comite des Reformes Sectorielles (CORES), deals with sectoral policies. A third committee, Comite pour la Dimension Regionale de l'Adjustement (CODRA), was created to insure consistency between the adjustment program and policies pursued under the regional integration initiatives, CBI, IOC and COMESA. The main purpose of its work will be to propose policy measures and follow up on their implementation. Objectives of the STA 13. The STA's responsibilities consist of (i) monitoring the ongoing economic and sectoral reform program, particularly the interpretation and analysis of macro-economic and social indicators; (ii) intensifying related economic dialogue and communication, and assisting the government in preparing discussions of a Policy Framework Paper (PFP) and SAC (ongoing); (iii) informing government agencies involved in the adjustment process, (iv) mounting a public information campaign on the adjustment program to mobilize broad based public support; and (v) organizing and supporting the dialogue between private sector organizations and the Government. 14. In monitoring the ongoing economic and sectoral reform programs, the STA regularly: (i) checks the status of reforms as defined in the government's policy matrix on--macro- I/ IDA funds under PPF, No. 919-MAG, have financed advisory services and equipment of the STA.

Furthermore, the STA helps prepare structural and sectoral reform programs and takes a leading role in coordinating and preparing the Policy Framework Paper 1996-98. It follows up on structural and sectoral policies and assists the authorities in the preparation of the policy dialogue that accompanies IMF/Bank-supported adjustment programs. Based on those activities, the STA produces such reports as a monthly assessment of the reform program (for the Government) and a quarterly bulletin (for the donor community). It also comments on and proposes corrections to all new draft legislation related to the adjustment program. 15. The second important STA function is to launch a wide-ranging public information campaigns to explain the adjustment process to the public. With technical assistance from two local communication specialists, and in close cooperation with the ministries concerned, it will organize seminars and workshops to familiarize members of the central and sectoral administrations, the private sector, and the public with the objectives of the adjustment process. USAID funded a participatory workshop in November 1994 and will support on-the-job training of the communication specialist. The workshop resulted in-the formulation of a communication strategy which has started being implemented. National media (radio, television, newspapers) will help disseminate the information. Issues to be Addressed 16. Working conditions. To fulfill its mission, the STA needs continuous, unimpeded access to economic and sectoral data plus the active support of the three associated committees, COREMEF, CORES and CODRA. COREMEF meets regularly to prepare monthly economic- indicator tables and a quarterly report on the implementation and impact of economic and financial reform measures. CORES works mainly on defining and executing sectoral strategies; it also supervises the activities of a committee (Comite de Suivi des Projets, CSP) designated to monitor the implementation of projects in the three-year rolling public investment program (PIP). This committee was first established in the context of the 1994 Country PortfQlio Performance Review of IDA-financed projects, and the government inÂ£tends to expand its scope to cover other projects in the PIP. In relation with adjustment process, CODRA harmonizes Madagascar' commitments in the context of regional cooperation; it coordinates the setting up of adopted measures by concerned departments. The three committees can be summoned on short notice by the STA to discuss urgent economic and sectoral policy issues. Regular meetings and information exchange are essential and should be monitored as one performance indicator of this component. The government has already devised a plan for a communications strategy in the context of a national communications seminar and has started to issue small publications on the adjustment program, targeted to the general population. Support to the National Institute of Statistics (INSTAT) Background and Overview 19. INSTAT compiles statistical data in Madagascar. INSTAT's main tasks are to produce national accounts, publish the consumer price index, compile statistical data on foreign trade and industrial production, and process civil service payroll data. The poor overall quality and reliability of data stem from several factors: uncertain collection at the source in terms of methodology, coordination, and consistency; and an outdated data base, national accounts system, and consumer price index (the base year for the index is 1972). There is a perceived need to strengthen the statistical system, and in particular, its capacity to produce national accounts, households surveys and business cycle surveys on a regular and timely basis. Objectives and Strategy 20. On the national accounts, the objective is to strengthen INSTAT's institutional capacity in order to produce an updated set of national accounts, which will provide a basis for the assessment of economic performance, for forecasts of medium-term economic development and for information requested by the private sector. 21. The proposed project will help INSTAT to prepare: the base national accounts for 1993, including a complete user's manual; methodology to prepare light annual accounts and compile the data base; yearly light accounts; and the projection of national accounts over three outer years. All activities will be accompanied by intensive training of the INSTAT staff members, including those involved in data collection at the regional level and the necessary acquisition of equipment. 22. The results of Madagascar's household welfare monitoring and analysis system, published in February 1996, will provide the basis for a number of analytical workshops, some

Workshop topics would cover agricultural sector activities, the informal sector, employment and income generation, and social sectors.-- They would follow up on the scheduled EDI-financed workshops on dissemination of the poverty assessment. To monitor living conditions over time and further develop the poverty profile, the proposed project will support the preparation of more selective permanent or priority surveys. That requires the definition of focus (household sample, theme) and methodology of priority surveys, as well as the preparation of a user's manual. Priority surveys will be undertaken every second year, starting in 1996. Price data and indices will be published on a permanent basis. 23. The objective of the project with respect to business cycle surveys is to assemble and train a permanent INSTAT team able to produce such surveys two or tree times a year. Its first task will be to prepare a user's manual to carry out the surveys. Support to the Departments of Finance, Budget, Planning and Economy Institutional Setting 26. The Departments of Finance and Budget are the central agencies charged with developing a financial, fiscal, and budget strategy for Madagascar. It manages state assets, the treasury, the budget, the payroll and, it also coordinates relations with some donor organizations (European Union, African Development Bank, FAC, Caisse Francaise de Developpement, etc...). 27. The Treasury (Direction Generale du Tresor) plays a key role in the management of public finance. It is responsible for fiscal receipts, payment of expenses, management of the State treasury, management of the public debt and securities (Portefeuille de I'Etat), and within the context of the implementation of the financial law, its accountants manage the State's accounts, ensure financial and accounting management of local governments and certain public autonomous agencies. Given the Treasury's evolving role and areas of interventions, as well as the increasing volume of operations, its goal of increased efficiency and effectiveness, an organizational audit of the Treasury will provide the basis for its reorganization. Many of the Treasury's procedures are outdated and are replete with manual tasks. Its personnel is in dire need of training (in-service), and the office of the Director General of Treasury needs to recruit competent technical staff, capable of executing the mandate of the institution today and in the future. 28. The Budget office (Direction du Budget) is responsible for the formulation, implementation and monitoring of the budget. The main activities are the coordination for
 10 budget forecasting analysis, the centralization of budget execution operations, the preparation of the budget regulatory law (loi de reglement), the financial oversight of state autonomous agencies, and the consolidation of Public Expenditure Programs (PEP), in close association with the Public Investment Office (Planning Department). 29. Payroll management (Direction de la Gestion Financiere du Personnel de l'Etat) for the entire civil service is under MFB's Directorate for personnel financial management About 90,000 agents are paid under the present system. The computerized preparation of the monthly payroll has been farmed out for years to the National Institute of Statistics (INSTAT). The computer equipment is outdated and more importantly, the procedures are cumbersome and inefficient. Four agencies intervene in the process: The Ministry of Civil Service (in charge of career management), the Directorate for personnel financial management, the INSTAT, and the Treasury (for payment); this results in long processing times and low reliability of payroll data. 30. The Planning and Economy Departments are known as the Direction Generale du Plan (DGP) and the Services de l'Economie. The Planning Department structure (DGP) in Madagascar consists of a central agency and sectoral and regional planning bodies, and is primarily responsible for economic planning and so for the coordination of design and implementation of economic, sectoral and regional policies. All government institutions, public enterprises and other public agencies operate under its authority in respect to public investment. The DGP is mandated to ensure (i) the annual preparation and the quarterly monitoring of the physical and financial execution of the public investment program (PIP), (ii) the consolidation of public expenditure programs (PEP) at a ministry level, (iii) the preparation of a regional development program, and (iv) the cooperation with donor agencies. The Economy Department structure is mandated to ensure the coordination of macroeconomic policies in close relation with STA (P.M.'s Office) and the newly created Secretariat Permanent a la Prevision Macro- Economique (Finance Department). a) Objectives and Strategy for the Finance & Budget Component 3 1. Assistance to specific units: The project aims at helping the authorities determine trade- offs between allocations for different types of expenditure and receive the needed information for fiscal policy . It will do this by assisting various units in providing the required information on the budget in a more transparent and timely manner: * Permanent Secretariat for Macroeconomic Forecasting: the main objective of the newly created "Secretariat Permanent i la Prevision Macro-economique", is to establish on a regular basis the macroeconomic framework and to analyze the policy options. * Treasury: the objective is to reorganize the Direction Generale du Tresor (DGT) to enable it, within the same payroll, to improve revenue collection and debt management, reduce disbursement lags under investment projects and improve budget programming and execution. With this in mind, the project will finance an organizational audit of the Treasury to provide guidance for the reorganization. The audit will review: (i) the Treasury's missions; (ii) the organization of central and regional services, their capacity to implement tasks assigned to them, human resources and equipment; (iii) the procedures for revenue collection; (iv) the accounting procedures, the information flow and the consolidation of accounts; (v) the causes for the delays in producing the yearly statements of budget execution; (vi) the Treasury special accounts covering earmiarked operations, with a view to budgetize them; (vii) the impact of the budget reform and the

The government has designed a work program for 1996-97 that includes (i) a training program of seminars and workshops to be held in Madagascar, as well as training abroad and (ii) specific technical assistance requirements as detailed below. The Direction Gneirale du Plan (DGP) and the Comite de Suivi des Projets (CSP) need to develop stronger analytical capacity to assess whether the proposed projects fit into sectoral, regional, and national economic policies and strategies, and have an impact on the fiscal balance and benefit the economy as a whole. The project will finance: * an Organizational Audit of the Planning and Economy Departments: The Departments of Plan and Economy are faced with a complex task resulting from the fusion of the old departments of Plan, Economy as well as the Directorate for Population. The organization of the Department of Plan and Economy is characterized by this fusion which is not adequate for its current ambitious mandate. The organizational audit will be carried out to:

B. StrengtheningPublicAdministration 1. Civil Service Reform Introduction and Overview 35. Profile of the Civil Service. The civil service in Madagascar has shrunk to a relatively modest size, representing approximately 1% of the population. Over the last 15 years, civil service salaries have decreased significantly in real terms. The new constitution (approved by referendum in September 1992) states that effective decentralization is an essential condition for the harmonious development of the sovereign Malagasy people. A new administrative structure encompassing central and local governments was laid out in draft legislation presented to parliament, emphasizing the need for effective decentralization, and the "deconcentration" of those services and functions which were to remain the responsibility of the central Government. Shortly afterwards, the Parliament passed a number of laws designed to apply this approach completely and consistently throughout the administration. These laws established the following principles: (i) powers were to be assigned to the various levels of local government in such a manner that costly and confusing overlaps would be avoided; (ii) the costs transferred to local authorities would be funded from their own resources; (iii)-taxes were to be specific, to allow for transparency and democratic control; (iv) local governments were to be managed by elected officials, without any central intervention other than that provided for by jurisdiction. 48. Nevertheless, problems arose as a result of the structure imposed by these laws, mainly due to a lack of the expertise and technical studies necessary to prepare their implementation. This had a negative effect on the viability of the many local government bodies that had been established, and the distribution of tasks and resources. A gradual introduction of the decentralization process as envisaged by the Government today, should help to address these problems. 49. In two reports to the Government (1994 and 1995), the Bank submitted recommendations regarding the following: (i) clarification of the distribution of fiscal resources; (ii) the need for more realistic budgeting, in particular without increasing the burden on the central government budget; (iii) improving collection of the local taxes that had been approved by vote, in order to increase local government resources; (iv) enhancing service delivery at local level by improving management, modernizing procedures, and (v) privatizing certain activities. The objective was to overcome the disadvantages of the previous system by establishing an institutional, administrative, and financial framework that would allow local governments to become active players in the development of their areas and to deliver their services efficiently. 50. According to the constitution, legislative provisions pertaining to local governments were supposed to be in place no later than March 1994. A Committee of Experts on Effective Decentralization (CEDE) was created in December 1993 and charged with preparing, carrying out, and coordinating all necessary studies, and implementing effective decentralization. The first municipal elections took place on November 4, 1995. An Interministerial Committee for Decentralization and Deconcentration (CIDD) will be created in August 1996 to replace the CEDE whose missions have been completed since the elections. The CIDD will be presided by a representative from the Prime Minister's Office, and composed of representatives from seven technical ministries. 51. Thus far, the authorities do not possess sufficient data and technical know-how/means to facilitate the smooth transition from a largely centralized government to a self-reliant local administration. An institutional framework, covering administrative as well as financial aspects, needs to be put in place to ensure the high quality and cost effective provision of local services.

Along with other former French colonies in Africa, Madagascar inherited at independence a legal system that was essentially of French origin. But the country also had a well-developed system of customary law, both written and unwritten, reaching back to pre- colonial days. The judicial sector has been deprived of the human and the physical resources it needs to perform its functions. The Laws 59. General. French law was formally introduced in 1895. In the absence of applicable provisions in the modem law, however, Malagasy courts still apply customary-law principles to the extent that they are ascertainable, well-established, and not contrary to public order or good practices. 60. The complex interaction between French and Malagasy law, coupled with the incidence of customary law, has created a situation where laws remain a matter of conjecture, thus making it difficult for practitioners to apply them correctly. Legislation governing commercial and business activities is largely outdated, and laws have not been readily accessible to users. Further, there has been no systematic coordination of law reform. 61. Commercial Code. The French Commercial Code, introduced in Madagascar in 1895, has often been amended by both the French and Malagasy legislatures. The provisions governing bankruptcies and company restructuring were amended in the early 1960s to make them more responsive to the modern business environment. Those provisions draw a sharp distinction between insolvent debtors who act in bad faith and deserve to be eliminated and others who act in good faith and deserve to be supported. The interests of creditors therefore receive greater consideration than those of enterprises and their employees. 62. The Registre du commerce was established for purely administrative purposes by a law dating back to 1919. In the course of time, the law has been amended on numerous occasions to allow it to play an increasingly prominent role in the disclosure of infornation pertaining to companies. In practice, the registre has been maintained in such a haphazard manner that the information it provides is neither complete nor reliable. 63. Company Law. The confusing state of company law is attributable as much to the scattered state of the legal texts as to inherent shortcomings in the legirslation. Five main types of companies are recognized in Madagascar. The Societt en nom collectif and the societt en commandite simple are both governed by the Code de Commerce. The Societt anonyme and Societe en commandite par actions are governed by a Malagasy law of 1867 as subsequently amended and the Societe ta responsabilite limitee by a French law of 1925 as subsequently amended. Other types of companies provided for under the law include the societes civiles, state-owned enterprises established by statute but operating as societts anonymes, and the so- called socialist enterprises, which were created during the socialist era. The laws creating the
 22 latter have been formally repealed by a 1992 law, which provides for the reconversion of socialist enterprises as societe's anonymes. 64. Civil Code. The Civil Code was amended in 1966 by a new law on contracts aimed at promoting security of transactions and incorporating lessons learned from experience. The new law seems to have achieved these objectives but does not, however, cover transport and insurance contracts, sales contracts, and other special forms of contracts that are expected to flourish in a liberal economic environment. The 1966 law has implicitly repealed all provisions of the French Civil Code relating to the general principles of contrac,s. All other provisions of the Civil Code remain unchanged. 65. Property Law. Title ownership is recognized under Malagasy law, as are other more traditional forms of land tenure. The attributes of title ownership replicate those of the Civil Code, but with qualifications designed especially to promote the productive use of land. Recent statutory and other instruments have severely restricted the rights of foreigners to own immovable property in Madagascar, making it virtually impossible for them to have access to immovable property, except by means of long term leases not exceeding 50 years in duration. 66. Banking Laws. Although banking legislation per se in Madagascar is of relatively recent origin, other legislative provisions governing banks are somewhat outdated. Some modern techniques used elsewhere to obtain credit are therefore not readily available. Similarly, in the absence of specific provisions governing leasing arrangements, there is no systematic recourse to leasing in banking transactions. The limited availability of land title registration, coupled with the unreliable and haphazard nature of the Registre du commerce, has had the effect of severely restricting access to credit based on land title or other forms of security. The Institutions 67. Organization of the Courts. Court organization is governed by a series of laws adopted in the early 1960s, including one governing the establishment of the Supreme Court and the Civil Procedure and Criminal Procedure codes. Following adoption of the 1992 Constitution and the realignment of some functions formerly vested in the Supreme Court, some of the legal provisions may have become obsolete. 68. The Constitution establishes an independent judiciary as a separate branch of the State (pouvoir judiciaire) and guarantees the independence of judges and magistrates. The two institutions responsible for enforcement of independence are the Supreme Court and the Constitutional, Administrative, and Financial Court (CAFC). 69. Higher Courts. The CAFC combines the Constitutional Court, Conseil d'Etat, and Cour des Comptes. The Supreme Court is the highest judicial court of the land. It hears appeals from the lower courts, but solely on points of law. It also supervises the judicial courts and ensures that judges, magistrates, and other judicial staff comply with the rules of conduct that govern their respective branches of the profession. 70. Lower Courts. The lower level courts consist of two distinct levels of jurisdiction, first instance and appellate. The Court of Appeal hears appeals against decisions of First Instance Tribunals. The First Instance Tribunal consists of civil, commercial, and social (labor) chambers. The social chamber hears disputes arising in the course of employment between
 23 employers and employees. In civil cases, the judge sits alone; in both commercial and labor cases, he is normally assisted by assessors. In civil and commercial cases, decisions of the First Instance Tribunals are normally subject to appeal to the Court of Appeal unless the amounts involved are relatively small. Objectives and strategy 71. Introduction. Given efforts to introduce a more liberal economic environment in Madagascar, there is growing concern about the unsastifactory state of the legal and judicial sectors. The government is fully committed to a strategy that seeks not only to modernize the legal system but also to restore the credibility of the judicial process. 72. Several studies and seminars on the legal/judicial environment have already taken place, including a landmark 1990 seminar on commercial and business laws sponsored by the Academie Malgache. In preparation for the proposed project, a diagnostic study of the legal and judicial environment was conducted in 1994, followed by a seminar to discuss the findings and recommendations. The govemment has assigined high priority to carrying out an inventory of existing commercial and business laws, verifying their continued validity, and thereafter publishing them as a complete set for the benefit of all public and private-sector employees, judges, magistrates, lawyers and other interested parties. 74. Legislative Reform Program. In order to streamline the legislative reform process, the government has decided to establish a Business Law Reform Commission, which will have primary responsibility for the supervision of the process of revision of business laws. The commission will consist of business and business law experts, including representatives of both the private and the public sectors. It will collaborate closely with the Ministry of Justice and share with it responsibility for the legislative reform process. 75. The Ministry's Direction des Reformes has been designated to draft legislation and act as secretariat to the commission. The Direction will need to be strengthened accordingly. Under the present regime, trainee magistrates are required, following their university education, to complete a two-year course at the Institut d'Etudes Judiciaires (IEJ). There is a growing perception that the IEJ has failed in the training task, at least as far as magistrates are concerned. Its course is also open to prospective barristers and legal consultants and is thus not particularly geared to the training of magistrates. In any event, due to lack of resources, IEJ has all but ceased to exist. 77. To ensure proper preparation in this vital area, the government plans to establish an Ecole Nationale de la Magistrature et des Greffes (ENMG) for the training and retraining of judges, magistrates, paralegals, and other court personnel such as court registrars.

Two other sets of issues merit discussion. First, the so-called proportional tax on court decisions is generally regarded as too high. The tax acts in effect as a disincentive for both the enforcement of judgments and the filing of appeals. Second, the procedures for the execution of judgments generate concerns, especially about the effectiveness of the procedures and the regulation, training, and fee scales of court ushers. 80. They range from poor salaries to lack of proper transport facilities, equipment, and material to inadequate provision of law books and library facilities. The proposed project would assist Madagascar at a critical time in improving the functioning of Government. It would help to lay the ground for a new approach to the

In summary, the project will benefit economic and social development by: * contributing to a broader based implementation of the adjustment program due to its internalization within the administration, private sector and civil society and wider consultation and coordination between ministries on policy measures; * improving the environment for savings and investment as a result of increased private sector confidence due to a more transparent legal framework and a more efficient functioning of the judiciary; * increasing the effectiveness of economic policies due to more timely and accurate statistical information and a stronger focus on monitoring poverty indicators. Even in the absence of an adjustment program, the project would be critical to improving public administration and building-up the capacity to elaborate and implement economic and institutional reforms. In the past the dialogue pursued. under the EMSAP project has been instrumental in fostering key reforms and avoiding back-tracking. b. Project risks 107. The strategy for change in public sector management and governance may encounter political resistance from vested interests. In contributing to improved governance, efforts involving decentralization and reform of the civil service and judiciary naturally come under political attack. Experience has shown that countries with unsettled political and fragile institutional environments present high risk factors with respect to the successful implementation of capacity building projects. The continuing political uncertainty, including recent changes in personnel in the Ministries of Finance, Budget and Planning hence add to project risks. Also, the full benefits of the project may take a long time to materialize and there is a risk that the commitment to reform may not be sustained long enough to provide lasting results. The risks involved in the legal and judicial component arise principally from the failure of all parties concerned to agree on a new definition of judicial independence, as provided under the Constitution. Now that there is a new government in place, there are hopeful signs that the issue is about to be resolved. Unless it can be resolved satisfactorily, there are risks that the component may not be able to achieve fully its objectives, and may have to be scaled down accordingly. 108. To help reduce the above risks, strong efforts have been made to encourage and help the project constituency to ensure a larger political consensus through close consultations with various stakeholders, including politicians in the government and the opposition, magistrates and other members of the legal professions, as well as private sector associations. The government has shown a capacity and commitment to reform by creating the STA and giving the institution the means to effectively coordinate the adjustment program, by improving its expenditure program and by taking unpopular but crucial measures in the macroeconomic field. Also, project risks have been reduced by assigning responsibility for the overall coordination of the project to the Prime Minister's office. The project has been designed flexibly to allow reassessment of issues and progress in light of long-term objectives as the project progresses.

The Government of Madagascar views the modernization and strengthening of government services as one of the cornerstones of its action program. The success of its economic development program largely depends on the successful adaptation of government services to the new role of the State. Henceforth, the State will concentrate on its essential functions and devote the bulk of its efforts to such priorities as poverty alleviation, primary health care, primary education, domestic security, and infrastructure maintenance. It will a'3andon its role as economic agent and will cease to wield heavy-handed control over private economic activity. 2. The purpose of the Public Management Capacity Building Project is to support this new approach. The general objectives of this project are as follows: . Modernize the government agencies by improving their organization, strengthening their technical capacities, and developing their human resources, thereby enabling them to effectively provide essential public services and support the country's development process. * Strengthen capacities for formulating, analyzing, implementing, and communicating the Government's economic development strategy, by developing the institutional capacity of the units responsible for economic affairs, and by strengthening the economic and social information system. * Improve the use of public resources by developing a transparent and efficient system of public expenditure management that will facilitate resource mobilization to support the essential functions of the State. * Modernize the legal system and reform the judicial system, to create a climate of confidence and an environment favorable to private investment, and to establish conditions conducive to good governance. * Strengthen the democratic process and deepen popular involvement in development activities through institutional capacity building within the decentralized authorities, enabling them to manage themselves and to fully assume the responsibilities conferred upon them by the Constitution.
 11. Context of the reform 3. The public sector reform project is taking place within the context of an economic development program formulated by the Government in its draft medium-tern Policy Framework Paper. The principal thrusts of this program are: (a) liberalization of the economy; (b) good macroeconomic management; (c) strengthening of human resource capacities; (d) openness to the world economy; (e) private sector development; and (f) the alleviation of poverty. Poverty alleviation is the Government's number one priority, which it will aim to achieve both through implementation of a strategy for a high and sustainable level of economic growth, and through the development of specific and targeted actions in the areas of health, education, and rural infrastructure development. The effectiveness and success of structural reforms will largely depend on the implementing capacities of the public authorities themselves. III. Specific objectives and actions planned 1. Strengthening of economic management 4. It is essential to strengthen the Government's capacity to prepare and formulate economic strategies and analyze their impact so that it can better shape its economic policy instruments and adjust them to the real needs of the economy while developing dialogue and consultation with the economic agents and the population at large. The specific objectives of this component are: * strengthen the capacity to formulate economic reform programs and monitor their implementation; * improve communications concerning economic strategy both within the government and with the public; * restructure the national accounts and the statistical system in order to provide the necessary information for management of the economy and of the reform programs. Action to achieve these objectives will include strengthening of the Technical Secretariat for Adjustment (STA) and the National Institute of Statistics (INSTAT). A. Implementation of economic reforms 5. STA component. This covers efforts to reach a nationwide consensus, and the preparation, coordination and monitoring of adjustment measures. The STA will be playing a more and more important role as coordinator and facilitator in the formulation and monitoring of economic and sector policies, with the active support of the two committees already associated with it: the Comite de Reformes Macro-economiques et Financieres (COREMEF) and the Comite de Reformes Sectorielles (CORES). In addition, the Groupe Technique de Travail de l'Initiative
 Transfrontaliere will be reconstituted as a third committee of the STA, to be responsible for the regional dimension of adjustment. 6. The holding of regular meetings, exchanges of information, and sensitization of the population to the economic reforns are all key indicators for an evaluation of the outcomes of this component. By the end of November 1995, the Government intends to have prepared a plan for a communications strategy within the framework of a national communications seminar. It also plans, by February 1996, to have short brochures published concerning the adjustment program, for distribution to the public at large. B. Development of the National Institute of Statistics (INSTAT) 7. INSTAT will improve the production and availability of reliable data to expedite economic policy choices, evaluation of the results of the reforms, and any necessary corrections. 8. With respect to the national accounts, the objective is to strengthen INSTAT's institutional capacities to produce those accounts on a regular basis. The first goal is the preparation of the 1993/1994 base accounts, from which aggregated/light annual accounts can be prepared at short notice. The Government confirms its commitment to produce, by April 1996, the semi-definitive national accounts for the period 1993/94, and, by December 1996, a methodology for establishing simplified accounts. 9. The results of the analytical surveys of household living conditions will serve as a basis for a number of analytical workshops, some of which will be entrusted with preparing a social accounting matrix. To monitor changes in living conditions over time and improve knowledge of the poverty profile, INSTAT will start in 1997 to carry out two-year permanent or more selective priority surveys. It will undertake each year, at appropriate intervals, to publish social indicators as a basis for assessment of the impacts of the Structural Adjustment Program. 10. Where conjunctural surveys are concerned, these will be carried out two or three times a year by a permanent team to be set up by [NSTAT in 1996. C. Financial and planning units 11. The Government intends to improve its efficiency, thereby arresting the deterioration of the public services, while also curbing government spending. Where the financial and planning units are concerned, expenditure programming and budgeting are two aspects desperately in need of overhaul. It is vital to ensure the highest possible return on government spending, while channeling that spending toward priorities, chief among these being poverty alleviation. 12. The principal objectives are: (i) increase transparency and rationality in the allocation and use of budgetary sources;
 (ii) assist the authorities to determine priority expenditures and to effect tradeoffs at both the intersectoral and the intrasectoral levels; (iii) improve the programming, execution and monitoring of public expenditure; (iv) improve the efficiency of the Treasury in order to strengthen budget implementation, assist with the preparation of periodic public expenditure indicator tables, and improve management of the public debt; (v) review the methods of management of the autonomous agencies to ensure that their operations and management are more transparent and more consistent with budgetary priorities; (vi) streamline the financial management of civil service staffs. 13. The following steps will be taken to facilitate all necessary change: (i) The Direction Generale du Plan will carry out supplementary analyses to determine whether the proposed projects are consistent with sectoral, regional and national economic strategies, whether they have any impact on budgetary equilibrium, and whether they are geared to the achievement of priority goals. (ii) The Direction des Investissements Publics and the sectoral ministries will improve sector policy design, expenditure management, implementation of the PIP and PEPs, and financial and physical monitoring of the PIP. In 1996, four ministries (Agriculture, Urban Development, Education and Health) will receive assistance to review expenditures in order to determine their consistency with sector policies and to decide on the allocation of operational. investment, and recurrent expenditures in the 1997 budget. The other ministries are slated to receive similar assistance in 1997. (iii) The Direction de l'Evaluation Economique, which in particular supervises the Comite de Suivi des Projets, will improve its capacity to monitor project implementation, enabling it to cover all large projects (over US$ 10 million) by 1997. (iv) It will collaborate with INSTAT in designing and preparing a quarterly publication containing economic data and information concerning investment projects. (v) The economic and planning departments will need to be reorganized in order to streamline human resource allocation and improve coordination with the finance and budget departments.
 (vi) The Direction du Budget will (a) improve the establishment and implementation of the public expenditure program and the monitoring of budget execution, to ensure that sector strategies are implemented within the constraints of the macroeconomic framework; and (b) undertake an audit of the autonomous public agencies for the purpose of making their operations and management more transparent. (vii) The Direction GCtnirale du Tresor will improve the efficiency of its organization and personnel, strengthen budget execution, draw up periodic public expenditure indicator tables, and improve management of the public debt. A Treasury audit will be performed for this purpose. (viii) Starting in 1997, the Direction de la Gestion Financiere du Personnel de l'Etat will introduce an efficient system of personnel financial management based on improved and simplified payroll processing and management procedures, thereby facilitating greater control over the wage bill and providing an overview of the principal data concerning civil service expenditures. 2. Strengthening of governance A. Civil service reform 14. The Government has decided to reform the civil service, with the following objectives: (i) adapt human resource management to the new role of the State resulting from privatization and decentralization, and to its new organization resulting from deconcentration; (ii) provide efficient public services and boost civil servant performance through a system of rewards and sanctions in the areas of career management and compensation: (iii) ensure participation by central government workers in the regional planning policy [politique d'amenagement du territoire] by seeing that they are evenly allocated throughout the country; (iv) enforce observance of the principles of political neutrality and public morality in the recruitment and management of civil servants and with respect to their behavior. 15. For reasons of efficiency, the Government intends to obtain comments and opinions from the administrative hierarchy, from representatives of government staffs, and from users,- concerning the content of its proposed policy guidelines and the modalities of their implementation. 16. It will proceed to a three-phase course of action:
 (a) Definition by the Government of the principal thrusts of civil service reform. (b) Strengthening of the consultation process through: * a study of each of two pilot ministries (Health and Education) * a series of national, sectoral and regional workshops designed to inform participants of the Government's policy guidelines and to obtain their specific proposals and, if possible, their adherence. (c) Definition, following completion of the studies and the national wrap-up seminar, of the legal and technical content of the reform, and submission to Parliament of those matters that concern it. B. Decentralization 17. To deepen democracy and establish more effective conditions within which to satisfy local needs. the Constitution makes provision for decentralization, a principle whose application will curb the role of the State, enable reductions in budgetary allocations and central government staffing, and thus deepen democracy. 18. With respect to those responsibilities that are to be retained by the State, the Government will apply the principle of deconcentration, thereby shortening the decision-making process. 19. Decentralization and deconcentration will be implemented in a coordinated and progressive manner. 20. In so doing, the Government aims to achieve a fourfold goal: (i) Given the extent of the needs that it will still have to fuifill, and given the budgetary situation, decentralization and deconcentration will have to be implemented at zero cost to the State budget. (ii) The decentralized local governments will need to have access to resources consistent with their new responsibilities. Consequently, as the State hands over its various responsibilities, it will also transfer the resources formerly available to it to finance the functions concerned. It also believes it is necessary to improve the effective yield of approved local taxes. (iii) In practice. responsibilities and the corresponding resources need to be clearly distributed between the State and each level of local government, both for operational reasons and to ensure a transparent democratic process.
 (iv) The principles of decentralization and deconcentration need to be very clearly stated. In particular, no new regional units of the central government should be created, even if that was formnerly intended as part of the transfer of responsibilities already or about to be transferred to the local authorities: Instead, any existing units should be eliminated once the responsibilities have been effectively transferred to the local authorities. 21. To this end, the Government envisions a three-pronged approach, whose facets are closely intertwined: (i) A series of studies on the allocation and clarification of responsibilities, the deconcentration of units and functions, local taxation, the instruments of a modem and efficient local government, and human resource management within the local authorities. Such studies need to form a coherent whole and include an overview and evaluation of the first phase, that of decentralization to the communes. It is essential that the Government have access to this overview and evaluation before it goes on to the later stages of decentralization to the other local government levels. (ii) Training of local government staffs in higher-level positions, since the rules and principles of good management will obviously have no effect if those applying them are not fully familiar with them. (iii) Six pilot operations in urban communes with significant fiscal potential; this action will not only support the operations of those communes themselves, but also, through its demonstration effect, be of assistance to the other communes. 22. The Government will take the following steps: (i) It will ensure the system's cohesion by expanding the role of the committee of experts on effective decentralization to include issues of deconcentration, will make the committee's prior opinion a mandatory requirement, and review the committee's composition in light of its expanded role. Those decisions will be taken by decree and set down in a letter of mission from the Prime Minister to the committee chairman. (ii) It will create a local finance commission bringing together local elected local officials and representatives of the government services to ensure the transparency of transfers of responsibilities and resources and exchanges of information.
 C. Reform of the legal system and of business law 23. The adoption of a new policy to liberalize the economic system has focused attention on the importance of the legal and judicial framework affecting the business sector. A number of studies and seminars have been conducted concerning the legislation in this area. 24. Those studies and seminars have revealed that a large part of the applicable legislation is outdated, going back as far as the colonial period. Some of the legislative texts have never been reformed, and are consequently unsuited to present-day circumstances. Others were amended or revised through the addition of certain provisions subsequent to independence. Even so. no systematic effort was made to coordinate those new provisions with the old ones. 25. Despite the importance assigned by the Constitution to independence of the judiciary, in several areas the institutions involved in that branch have little credibility. This is because of the persistent neglect of the legislative provisions in those particular areas. and also because of the Government's long-standing role as sole arbiter of the country's economic activities. 26. Within the context of its policy aiming to stimulate initiative and promote the private sector, the Government intends to adopt all necessary measures to rehabilitate the appropriate legal and judicial institutions and restore their credibility. Among those measures, the Government is firmly resolved to make available to the Ministry of Justice and the judicial institutions the resources essential to the achievement of their objectives. 27. To this end, the Government has already set up a business law reform commission to supervise and coordinate the legislative drafting process. This commission will be working in liaison with the Ministry of Justice and the other ministries concerned, with a view to the preparation of new laws and regulations. The commission and the Ministry of Justice will together draw up a five-year timetable for business law reform. The primary focus will be reform of the investment credit law, involving a radical overhaul of commercial securities and publicity, of company and business group law, of land law and labor law, and of the rules of bankruptcy and procedures governing court supervised restructuring of companies. Faced with the tasks of implementing legal reforms and drafting new legislation, the Ministrv of Justice will need to hire additional staff and take on consultants to meet its necessary complement of human resources, and will also need to have access to the requisite material resources. 28. To improve the prestige and restore the credibility of the judicial institutions, a special effort will be made to improve the working conditions, environment, and material resources of those employed within the judicial system. To this end, the Government undertakes both to ensure their independence and freedom of activity and to protect them against arbitrary professional sanctions. 29. Upgrading of the status of judges and improvement of their work environment also depend on the availability of material resources. A study of the material circumstances and incomes of the country's judges should be conducted without delay. In the meantime, a measure to substantially
 increase the housing allowance of those judges who are not provided with government housing will take effect on January 1, 1996. 30. The wheels of justice generally grind very slowly, a fact that tends to discredit the judicial system. To encourage judges to be diligent, the Government intends to introduce a performance bonus, to be awarded on the basis of clearly defined criteria. Application of those criteria should provide the necessary incentive for courts to improve upon their performance.. 31. As part of the effort to promote and modernize the judicial system, new facilities and new resources will be granted to make library facilities available to the judges, whether they be trial judges or magistrates attached to the Ministry of Justice. [magistrats du siege et du parquet]. A law review will also be established, which will periodically publish the principal court decisions and the principal laws and decrees that have recently been enacted, together with comments by legal scholars or theorists. 32. In addition, every possible effort will be made to improve the operation of the courts, in such areas as exchanges of pleadings [mise en etat des affaires] and summary proceedings in cases of urgency [uridiction des referes qui statue sur les cas d'urgence]. Measures will also be taken to lessen the difficulties of enforcement of court decisions. To that end, a study will be conducted with a view to modifying the laws applicable to those areas within the framework of a new judicial procedure. This study will focus in particular on the advisability of eliminating the taxe proportionnelle, one of the main reasons for the excessively slow process of enforcement of court decisions. Lastly, a school for judges will be established [Ecole de la Magistrature], to facilitate the hiring and training of new judges. This school will also provide conhinuing training for existing judges and court officials (targeting clerks of the court in particular). The Government undertakes to provide the school with the necessary resources to ensure its sustained and continuing operation. IV. Organizational and institutional aspects 33. The Government attaches the greatest importance to the success of the institutional reform and public sector capacity building project. It therefore finds it essential to set up a system that will ensure the coordination and efficient management of the project, both overall and where each individual component is concerned. The project comes under the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance and Budget, who will appoint a General Project Coordinator to ensure that its implementation adheres to the Government's guidelines. Each of the seven components will come under the auspices of the ministry concerned, and will be coordinated by a senior official appointed for the purpose, who will be responsible for its implementation. The Government will entrust the project's financial management to a Project Unit managed by a Project Director, to coordinate procurement, disbursements, accounts, and auditing.
 VI. Conclusion 34. The public sector reform and capacity building project is consistent with the Government's economic program and will support the Government's efforts to restructure the public sector and to endow it with the dynamism and efficiency essential to the success of the economic reform program and of the strategy to boost the country's economic development. 35. The project will contribute to capacity building of the capacity within both the central and the decentralized local governments, rendering them more capable of performing their respective functions and of ensuring greater participation by the people and the communities in the preparation and implementation of development strategies. doc.abstracts: The Public Management Capacity Building Project will provide assistance to the government of Madagascar in the areas of economic management and public administration. Its objectives include: (A) to improve the government's capacity to design and implement an economic reform program and contribute to a sharper focus on poverty alleviation in allocating public resources; and (B) to facilitate a fiscally responsible implementation of the decentralization process, foster participation in local planning and management of the development process, catalyze consensus building on civil service reform within the administration, and improve the security of business transactions. The project components are to: (1-4) provide support to the Technical Secretariat for Adjustment, the National Statistical Institute, the Departments of Finance and Budget, and the Departments of Planning and Economy; (5) reform civil service; (6) decentralize the government; (7) reform the judiciary; and (8) strengthen the Project Management Unit.
